I wanted to like this game, I really did. I went in with an open mind and an open heart and I left 40 hours later severely disappointed. Watch_Dogs has everything I love in a relaxing game: a big open world for getting lost, driving, stealth gameplay, cyberpunk, all sorts of elements. For as big and complex as the game world is, however, Watch_Dogs is incredibly empty.  Watch_Dogs has you controlling Aiden Pearce, master hacker and parkour enthusiast, as he hacks his way through a futuristic security network linking all of Chicago. The game world has, by far, some of the best object modelling and NPC generation I've seen to give the urban environment of Chicago a living, breathing feel. Yards and sidewalks have clutter that changes with the socio-economic level of different parts of town and as Aiden free runs through back yards or across apartment complexes, it's not unlikely you'll trip over barbeque pits or shopping carts reasonably placed in real world settings. NPC's look varied and react differently to your actions and, after a while, the environment does feel sentient.  The fantasy stops there, however, as the graphics, which you've no doubt heard by now, have been so watered down from the E3 demo that they look almost cartoonish. The color palette is off with a base-level shade spectrum you don't see in the real world, and the textures are clean and flat to the point of almost appearing two dimensional. Shading is apparent but thin, debris is minimal, and even in hot and heavy gunfights and car chases, everything just looks so mild. There are a lot of objects being rendered and maybe that's why the textures are so muted, but when Grand Theft Auto 4, 2008, and especially Assassin's Creed, 2007, look better than Watch_Dogs, one wonders why it was released at $65.   The driving, a major part of the game, is just absurd. Almost all of the cars are modeled the same way, poorly. Whether it's a 70's muscle car or Euro exotic, they all have back ends that float away on the corners and send you crashing left and right. I stuck to the same motorcycle throughout the game, wasting some beautiful artwork crafting dozens of useless cars. Collision detection was almost non-existent except for head-on impacts, and body damage on vehicles seemed almost random at times, with odd dents appearing on places where the car was not touched. Very poorly done.  The gameplay mirrors the graphics with a dull story that ignores the surrounding elements of advanced technology, privacy, illegal searches, totalitarianism, and even human trafficking, and settles on a simple but convoluted revenge story. The voice acting is decent but story elements are for naught and some are just stupid, like a main character dying in an odd setting for no reason, and a plot twist at the end that bears no consequences. I'm curious if the people that wrote the plot were even shown the game they were supposed to be following.  The game is divided into several smaller missions that almost play out exactly the same almost every time. The same objectives, the same enemies, it's just tedium after a while. The 'hacking' is non-existent as checking people's phones or activating cameras is done with the Q key automatically. Breaking into a system uses the old water pipe puzzles from Flash games you could play for free on the Internet. PC Gamer reported in 2013 that the developers were utilizing real cybersecurity experts to consult for the game, and I really can't see where their tutelage was utilized. At least the gunfights were fun, which they better be considering you can carry an obscene amount of guns and explosives on your person. The worst of all this, however, was when the objectives were completed and I was given the option to kill all the enemies or leave the area. I walked away almost unchallenged, and I did this repeatedly on the hardest difficulty setting. After doing what I was supposed to do, I just ran from the area with maybe a short car chase or helicopter pursuit, but in the end I truly just left the scene unchallenged. There's a 'bullet time' mode for when the going gets tough called 'Focus'. I made it through the entire game on hard without having to use it once.  Watch_Dogs offers no challenge, not as a game nor as an intellectual topic. I put 40 hours into this game feeling like I had wandered about a beautiful, yet flat, setting for no reason whatsoever. It saddens me because I know the painstaking detail that went into developing the game world, but in the end there's no reason to go back to it after finishing the story. I could go wrap up the massive amount of side quests and secondary objectives but why? If you played one you've experienced all of them. Watch_Dogs is a pointless trip down busy streets, and in the end I felt less of a hacker and more of a digital tourist.

This is a fantastic game that is a lot of fun to play. I did have the stuttering issues that have been reported widely on the web, but was able to tweak the game and graphics settings to mostly eliminate them. The key seemed to be to dial down the anti-aliasing setting and turn off motion blur. I do have a graphics card with 3GB of RAM which let me use the ultra textures. I'm also able to run with ultra reflections which make the wet streets during rain and Aiden's wet clothes look fantastic. Hopefully the stuttering issues will be addressed by a performance patch. I would recommend waiting to play the game until the patch has been released to avoid being frustrated and disappointed by the stuttering issues. Once past these issues, I have been having a lot of fun driving and walking around Chicago as well as playing the missions. The game lets you chose your approach: You can sneak around and even remotely invade an area via the security cameras. You can also go in guns blazing, if you prefer. Or you can mix the two approaches as you see fit.  The Metacritic score is much lower than the game deserves. I suspect it is due to the performance problems at launch.

I don't know what every one was expecting this game to be but its in no way GTA on steroids. You have to come into this game with the right mindset. If you are a fan of Person of Interest I would highly recomend this game. But to the average person no.  The graphics are okay. They pulled a Far Cry 3 on this. Nothing like the E3 demo. But I'm not here really to complain about the GTA Vice City textures ported over to the AssCreed engine.  The game was advertised as everyone and everything is connected. And that you actions will have serious repercussions based on what you do. Not only could I just walk into a gun store and buy an assault rifle right after escaping the cops with no question asked and hang around for 10-15 minutes. Nothing happened as I hacked another 20 bankaccounts during my casual stroll through the Park for the 40th time. I tried not to kill anyone during the game by either using melee or shooting them in the leg. Unfourtionaly no matter where or how you hit them they will die. As I discovered this by shooting an officer in the leg to where it said Officer homicide and knocking another one down with the melee to where it also said office homicide.  On a postive note the enemy AI is pretty advanced. They will give supressing fire while their team mates flank around to the other side. However the saim can't be said for the Allied AI. They will stand around and take bullets thinking they are ♥♥♥♥ing superman. While you are forced to try and protect them from their own poorly coded thinking 'skills.' But by far the worst is the civilian AI. I'm in a massive shootout between several guys and some how a small group of ♥♥♥♥ing civies keeps walking back and fourth between the crossfire avoiding every bullet. And for some reason the people 5 feet away don't get the memo and proceed to walk into the crossfire only freaking out as a bullet or 2 wiz by them. Slowly building up the amount of civilians trapped in the crossfire. Seriously one time there was 15 of them I couldn't get a shot off to save my life. So I just gunned all of them down.  I never really thought of Hacking as something big in this game. Just a gimmick. And while it is really a gimmick it also very useful and funny at times. Remeber when I said the civi AI is out right stupid in the last paragraph. Well when you hack the traffic light to make them all green. All cars will proceed to drive foward or make wide angle turns regardless of what is in front of them. I saw a lone car at a traffic light. I decided to do something nice and change it for him. He proceeded to make a wide angle turn into a wall. Note there were no other cars around. A second time I parked a Dumptruck infront of an intersection. I hacked the light greed and all the cars proceeded to drive stright into said dumptruck despite the fact it haddn't moved at all.  The story while meh at times really make you feel like an action hero. In my case Mr. Reese from POI. But after the story is over there is really nothing to do other than stop petty robberies or play chess. This game needs a level replay function. Something that should be standard in every game. This is a game that honestly need mod support. A reason I keep going back to games like GTAIV instead of something like Sleeping Dogs. With out a big mod community even with all its Multiplayer Features I see this game dieing in a few months (at least on the PC) with only a handful of people comming back to it to get their Batman with guns stopping petty crimes fix.  Also if you have an AMD card. This game runs like a blind paraplegic walking up a flight of stairs if you don't have a Nvidia card. I would also like to note that this game is currently ported (or in the process of being ported) to all the 7th and 6th gen consoles (excluding the Wii) Only the PS3 is using a Nvidia Graphics Chip. The PS4, BXO, 360, Wii U all have GPUs made by AMD. From what I've heard they run perfiectly fine on those AMD based systems. Yet my Overclocked 7970 seems to be having a hard time pulling off High Setting, Medium Textures, AA off. While Nvidia Users with a less than equlivant card seem to pull off Ultra setting with little to no problem. There is perfered optmization, unoptimazation, then there is this ♥♥♥♥.  Unless you really need a Person of Interest type game like me. Avoid this disapointment espically if you are an AMD user. At least for now.

Watch Dogs is a game that lets you experience stealth in a massive way like no other game I’ve played. While most games will let you silently take down a target in close proximity, and Watch Dogs does this too, not many allow you to stand outside of a building, hack security cameras to profile your target, and then laugh manically while you explode them with their own grenade and watch the rest of the enemies flip out because they can’t find you.  The gameplay is fantastically fun and unique, allowing you to hack a large number of combat and stealth devices, giving you the choice to either sneak by, silently take down, or full-out assault a group of enemies, and the game doesn’t penalize you for your choices. You also have a number of thrilling hacks while driving, like exploding steam pipes to take down your pursuers or changing traffic lights to cause mass-accidents. It was very rewarding to unlock new things to hack and new combat skills as I progressed through the game. The story was average (albeit with great voice acting), and the earlier tutorialized missions were too drawn out like most Ubisoft games.  For the most part I decided to stay focused on the main missions rather than most of the fun, but overwhelming, side content. The game itself is plenty long enough to enjoy without even touching the side content, although I recommend at least trying some out because a lot of them are quite fun, like missions where you must destroy a moving target before it reaches a destination by booby trapping the route or chasing the enemy down. There's a lot of something for everyone.  If you're looking for an Open Word game where you can run around and cause mass chaos, you'd be better off with the Grand Theft Auto series or Just Cause 2. There are also some bad stuttering graphical issues that made me restart a checkpoint or two.  P.S. People that complain about the cars -- some cars handle better than others per design (just like GTA), and you need to learn to use the hand break and have a subtle touch to the joystick. Then no issues. The motercycles are nice too.  4/5  TL;DR: FUN combat with your choice of stealth + action; intense car chases; average story; not a ton of sandbox elements in this open world

Played the game long enough to finally give an accurate review.  The first cutscene/mission starts...you tweak the settings have a look around and start playing. The game looks great, the interiors are very polished...can't wait to see the city! That's when it goes downhill graphics wise. The first car you get in, it's like you've bought a cheap knock off of the original footage of Watch_Dogs (which, really, you have). The cars are horrid on the graphics side of things. And they all have an annoying screen vibrate and burnout every time you take off. Is this 1997?  Now we get around to the story. You don't feel immersed, you don't feel attached to any character, you can see the deaths coming, and you see how each and everyone fits a cliche. Some of the jokes the hitman (see I can't even remember the names) accomplice makes just make you cringe. Not to mention the lame memes you can hack on to road signs.  Gameplay. This was the only thing I enjoyed. I loved sneaking around gang hideouts, and using the hacking mechanic to my advantage. I enjoyed the charge-in firefighting when intercepting a convoy and the realistic way the citizens reacted. I knew this wasn't GTA going in, so just randomly running over people on the sidewalk actually made you not want to do it after the first time you drove around like a maniac. Unless you wanted your rep to be bad anyway, which I did play with after finishing the campaign.  After the campaign (which is very short at 12 hours give or take) all that's left is the gang hideouts, contracts, convoys, etc. Pretty much like Far Cry 3 but a way shorter campaign. I completed most of it, but didn't really care for the fixer contracts.  At glance, it looks like I wouldn't recommend it. After installing the 'E3 2012 mod' it helped out with the city look, but those buildings at night are just no where near what you expected. The game without the E3 mod looks like GTA IV with iCEhancer...except it's Chicago...and the car graphics are bad.   All in all though, I do recommend the game. Yeah, it's 60 dollars, but I got my money's worth out of it. Graphics/story/longetivity aside, it's a neat take on GTA style sandbox games and it's fun. Maybe they will learn from this and put out a decent sequel with the original graphics they show for it.

They're working on a patch, but most people are going to be done with the game.  Now time for the good stuff. The hacking. At first I was very disapointed in the hacking, thinking it was missing something, it needed this oompf, but after I played more of the game, I came to the conlcusion I really liked the super simple hacking, that everything is connected at one touch on the screen. The weapon and vehicle variety. I really liked the 'car on demand' app, letting you have a car (outside of missions) whenever you want, with a nice variety of car types. Same goes to weapons, 4 kinds of guns, and it's all you need. Each and every single one of them being fun. The story (this includes the characters). I enjoyed the story, except the odd 'plot' twist ending. I liked the idea of getting with a small gang and hacking the city and its people to conclude a missing link in Pierce's life. Watch Dogs brings us to a whole other level. It really reminds me of Assassins Creed 4, since there's these towers that you can explore, and they give you different kind of stuff to do. Watch Dogs does provide us with alot of gameplay such as minigames, crimes to beat to justice, exploring, campaign missions, and more. And the most important part is the hacking. This is why this game is so amazing. All the people you see on the streets aren't the same. They've all got different personalities and pasts, which you can 'hack' through your cellphone. Not only you can hack the persons information, but you're in control of the whole city as well.

Don't listen to all the people that call this game a copy-off of GTA. There are plenty of open world crime drama games; Mafia 2, Sleeping Dogs, LA Noire to name a few. Sure this game is a little rough around the edges but it's the first in what could be a long series of good games. I would recommend this game to anyone however I rate it 3.5 out of 5. I would give it and extra .5 if they fixed some of the lagging and 'rougher edges' of the game, another .5 if they made the season pass more worth it with more large DLC's similar to the Bad Blood DLC, and the last .5 if they made the world a little more interactive like GTA V. Overall though, those are all small changes compared to the game as a whole and Watch Dogs ranks among my most favorite in the crime drama genre.

Against: 1º First When it comes to open-world games I preferred playing GTA V : in the beginning I thought that the Hacking mechanics would be awesome and game-changing and would make this game better than GTA V in intereactions with the world , but in the end it felt like there weren't as many things as I had hoped when I saw the trailers . The Hacking mechanics felt a little glitchy sometimes ( this opininon can be ignored for the reasons in nº2) , and would sometimes end up having opposite effects to what I initially hoped for. 2º If you really whant to enjoy this game you must have a top notch gaming PC: Part of the reason i felt unninterested is because my PC is not the best gaming PC ever , it's a medium gaming PC , but It lacks RAM memory , while games on average have as their minimum 4 GB ram , that means I get to play (even if it's a little less HD ) but the need that this games has of 6 GB of RAM makes it almost impossible to play at times. I have about 8GB RAM , and a huge part of it (about 3-4 GB is used for secondary processes) and that leaves me with 4-5 GB RAM , and that sucks ,seen as GTA V has amazing graffics and the minimum required is 4 GB it's playable even for people that don't want or can't afford a top notch Gaming PC. In Favor: 1° Hacking : The hacking mechanics althought glitchy and sometimes broken they can , if used correctly , bring life in the game. This brings some humor to the game , wherether looking at a funny conversation about a guy who got the wrong toy model or seeing a Blood donor that has HIV positive , it makes you laugh . and can even give you an edge on combat or in stealth missions. It's an ok machanic but sometimes broken , but when it works , it's awesome. 2º On-line mode: One of my favorite thing about this game is the on-line mode, It's such a good feeling when you invade a friend or a random player and you blend in with the crowd and they never find you while you're hacking them unnoticed. Also the Game-Phone car thing , was really interesting. Sometimes when you are invaded some weird stuff happens , for example I just got in my motorcycle , and as I was starting to accelerate the screen warned me I was being invaded and so I started the engines and started to ride but I accidentaly ran over a pedestrian , turns out the pedestrian was the invader, what a surpries. Conclusion :  In the end the game is fun and interesting , but could have been a lot better made and it was unlucky because it had to live by the shadow GTA V . I recommend it but only if you have a PC that is capable of running it , and you have extra dollars in your pockets , otherwise I fell as other games such as GTAV or Assassin's creed series are a better sugestion

However, up until the eighth hour I had been running with the graphics set on high except motion blur was off (I just hate motion blur) and the game had been running fine, there were no problems with Fps and I had seen very few graphical, or any, glitches at all. However in this past hour where I have tried to boot the game, with the same graphical options, I am met with Fps lag galore and lighting glitches to cobble dogs with. I have no idea where this came from at all and as far as I can tell it is nothing to do with my machine.  Maybe it was just too good to be true that the game would be working well so soon after release. What was I thinking that after it had been delayed and so heavily hyped that it would be completely polished. Game itself was good, optimisation and general behind the scenes work of the game not so much.

About two years ago, a game named Sleeping Dogs came out. In that game, you played Wei, an undercover cop operating in deep cover within Hong Kong's Triad underbelly. There were plenty of things for Wei to do (read: optoinal side quest objectives) which spanned the gamut from racing, to gambling to takedowns. You, as Wei, could also cruise around town buying (or stealing) cars, outfits and the like.  Watch_Dogs is almost exactly that game, even down to the name. Instead of a cop, you control Aiden, a hacker and vigilante, meaning that you also are running in the dirty underbelly of the city (Chicago instead of Hong Kong). There are, however, a few things that set it apart from it's spiritual predecessor:  Aiden's phone: This little gem is the source of all of Aiden's hacking powers. With the city linked into Chicago's citywide operating system, the whole game world is Aiden's hacking playground. It can be used for tasks as small as changing the channel on a shopkeeper's radio all the way up to things like turning the power off in a city district. When in Scan Mode, it even lets you scope out detials on NPC's, presumably by raking up data on them from their phones as well as by notes made by the ever present CTOS (network). While knowing that the guy ahead of you is a 34 year old line cook that gives to schools might not sound like much, it goes a long way into making the world seem that much more real and interesting.  Online play: A very short time into the main storyline, you get forced into an 'Online' mode tutorial, which introduces you to the whole concept. Essentially, this pits two players against each other as they race to accomplish individual, competing mission goals. These little contests can crop up just about anywhere at any time, and adds an interesting dynamic flair to the game. Sometimes there's a trigger: a NPC you've hacked places a hit on you which is then offered up to a player. Mostly, however, it's a bit more free form than that. You'll be cruising around town when all of a sudden you notice that someone's hacking you, or you are informed that there's a street race about to happen. All in all, it's another interesting level of immersion that keeps you on your toes.  In the end, Watch_Dogs doesn't feel like it's innovating so much as parroting. Still, it's a fun, engaging title that will hack into your life as you explore what this digital version of Chicago has to offer.

I'll give it straight. Am I enjoying this game, yes. Would I reccomend it to my friends? No.  First off, if you're playing with an AMD card like me, stop. Right now. You will get 30 FPS running on Medium even though your computer can handle Ultra.   Secondly, to address the major elephant in the room: Yet again Ubisoft's servers can't handle this game. I think I've only been hack attempted by REAL players (You have two missions where you chase after disguised bots) once, and even then they disconnected within a few seconds.  Now for the major plot points. Aiden Pearce is essentially Bruce Wayne with his mask down, and Batman with it up. The story seems peeled right out of any of the Arkham games. Yes it's an accurate representation of Chicago. Yes it does have multiplayer. Yes it does look nice if you can manage to pump the graphics before you crash.   The point is, it lacks quite a bit, and Ubisoft has done much better. This game is plagued by the open world problem of 'side quests consist of game time so lets make a 10 hour story.' I personally had no real problems with 'Press X to be cool' until you realize most of the free hacks are instant kills in a bubble area. For those of you averse to it, there are cover based shooter mechanics, and the stealth system only turns on automatically, you can't choose to activate it.  Cars handle like you're playing Mario Kart. Essentially with the hacks, it is Mario Kart and the blue shell is the steam pipe.   Plot wise, most characters have sub-par voice acting, and Aiden constantly sounds like he's trying really hard to crap his pants. The only decent voice actor I found was the female hacker, but she falls victim to the sexual tension trope because she's the only female in the game whom Aiden interacts with frequently that isn't related to him. Not once have I been surprised by the plot, it's all predictable and taken from most crime dramas/Batman comics.  Honestly, there's more but I don't really keep track. Point is, save your money. Buy A Cool Story About My Uncle or something.

Best way to explain Watch_Dogs is Grand Theft Auto and Assassin's Creed with a pinch of Metal Gear Solid.  But really it doesn't use the best of all 3.  It's a weaker version of GTA with less attention to detail. The Motorcycles, Cars, Music, and Missions are like a watered down but still okay version. It's kinda fun, but there is no life to it. There are far less easter eggs and the side missions are mostly annoying and extremely similar. Part of what made GTA amazing was it's massive attention to detail and freedom to just go out and have fun. Watch_Dogs just pales in comparison to the game that obviously inspired it.  The Parkour and styling of Assassin's is in there all over the place too, but not fully. It's frustrating at times using the cover system, and there is virtually no melee attacks/weapons. It's kinda clunky and doesn't work well. After several hours, you get the hang of it and work with it, instead of it working for you.   MGS but only in spirit. Trying to be stealthy almost always becomes too much work with little reward. With it's futuristic feel with the stealth and technology, it will remind you of the good ol' days with Snake. Sadly though I've given up with being sneaky in the game all the time and only do it to get an advantage over enemies until literally blowing everything up with grenades using machine guns. There are a few 'Stay out of sight' missions, but they are too easy and predictable as well.  What's good? The hacking portions that act as sort of super powers are fun, and the gunfights are fun as well, but I wish I wouldn't have paid $60 for it. There is just too much filler in the story line involving almost identical missions and no sense of urgency. The Story line is really weak as well. Your character Aiden Pierce is too much of a cheesy mysterious tough guy and the plot is really contrived. It's all really predictable. I could write about how the plot is really bad as well, but that would just be the cherry on top.   It's not what it could have been. It could have been gripping, suspenseful, action packed and detailed. But nope. It seems like it can't decide what it wants to be. a Sneaky Espionage game with futuristic powers? A run and gun have fun 3rd person shooter? An Open world sandbox where you can do whatever? how about all 3 but not as good as they could have been separately and for that matter you'll beat it in just 4 days.  Not worth $60

Set in an alternate universe where Chicago's gangs are mostly entitled whites , you play as the un-charismatic emotionless protaginist known only as 'Watch underscore Dog'. After your grandfater kidnaps your sister, you embark upon a mighty quest to discover useless trivia about your city's inhabitants using your state of the art Motorola RAZR. But your leek skills dont stop there, 'cause this games a whole different vegtable. With that same nokia home phone, you can become the public servant mr. Watch underscore Dog was born to be; raise bridges to let boats pass, help security staff by monitoring their cameras for them, and even go so far as to burst unstable pipelines (since pipelines run on electricity and require TONS of wires) so thankful construction crews can earn a living. After learning that your blackberry company phone is a prototype, and little more than a gimmick, you can move on to where this game truly shines, the driving! Ubisoft partnered with the creators of 'The Urbz: Sims in the City' to bring the most life-like driving straight to the Gamecube. Go from zero to 60 in .5 seconds and stay that fast, since Ubisoft realised that driving any slower, or faster, or even turning in any direction, is not what people want out of the high octane world of virtual car handling. But enough about Ninten-dogs, back to the engaging story. After you rescue your sister from your aunt by staring at your phone all day, Watch underscore Dogs is free to roam around the bustling city scape at his leisure. And thank god he likes to walk around, (he tried driving, but 60mph was too much) because this Chicago is emptier than a strip club on a Tuesday afternoon (developer note: buying the season pass for $19.99 gives you immediate access to 'Your Pole, My Heart', a dating sim featuring five strippers of questionable health and genitalia). Since Ubisoft saw that games like GTA had an open world, and they sold well, they'd try making an open world Chicago, except instead of putting any form of co-op goofieness or well thought out minigames, they added the ever popualr 'stare down at flip phone: wait for artifical gameplay' to give you a nice break from the main story's 'Stare down at my pay-as-you-go phone'. All in all, Ubisoft once again gave it their best, and produced a game that could only come from the same company that brought you stea- i mean uplay and 'Open Season: The GAME'  I give it 5 phones out 60, buy it today and support upla- i mean Steam!

I was really looking forward to playing this game and pre-ordered it, which isn't something I do very often anymore. Unfortunately Ubisoft has shoveled out yet another game with no regard to product quality. This is a company I once held faith in to release excellent quality, well designed games, but this isn't the case anymore. FC3 is the only quality product they have released in over two years. AC3 was horribly buggy (the DLC particularly was so riddled with bugs and poor design that it was mostly unplayable), and while I enjoyed Black Flag, it wasn't much better (the free running on ships was so broken that it felt like it hadn't even been tested). While not nearly as broken as AC3, Watch Dogs is still a disappointment. Below are some of the major problems.   - The game regularly crashes (running on a Win7 rig with an intel i5-4440, GeForce GTX 650 Ti 2GB with latest certified drivers, and 8GB RAM), regardless of what video settings are used. - The Driving mechanics are horrible. Overly sensitive steering, even using a 360 controller, and the camera takes far too long to snap back behind the car, making it difficult (and in some cases impossible to see where you are going). Since a significant portion of the game revolves around driving, more care should have been given to the controls to make sure they felt right. As is, driving can be an excersize in frustration. - Broken/useless game mechanics: One example - Players can acqure an ability to disable police/enemy helicopters, and the ability is practically required for escaping police with a high wanted level, but police helicopters hover directly over the character (or car), which prevents you from even using the ability. - Tons and tons of map bugs. - Game settings don't save when set in-game. If you change settings from the pause menu, they will revert back the next time you launch the game (this should be a standard test case for any game that has settings that can be changed during gameplay).  There is much more, I could easily go on all day listing all the bugs I've seen in the game. However, I could fogive many of them if the game didn't crash and all of the core game functionality worked right.   Now, there is a lot that works really well in the game, which is why I keep playing. I would avoid this game until its in the bargain bin.  The gameplay centers around 3 mechanics.  1)Combat, which plays like every other shooter game. It includes an ability called focus which is used to slow time down. Would be more impressed with it if such a gimmick wasn't as old as dirt by now. Combat AIs aren't bad, but they're not particularly dangerous either.  2)Hacking, basically find something to hack, then hold down q for 1 second. Somtimes involves a little puzzle for more 'secure' systems. Can affect some physical objects, which can be amusing the first time. 10 minutes into the game, it is repetitive and boring, though occasionally useful when paired with the 3rd mechanic.   3)Driving- I probably spend over 3/4 of the game in one car or another. So many of the main quests and side contracts require a car chase, either as the pursuer or the rabbit. Its a little fun at first to drive some of the faster vehicles through traffic, but again, it gets old a bit quick. Traffic is ridiculously light for a major city like chicago. 90% of the time its perfectly safe to blow through intersections without slowing. There are no police on the streets unless a citizen calls them. So literally it becomes set the waypoint on the map and follow the arrows to it at full speed.  Story is so-so. Starts off weak and cliched, gets a little better as it goes on, but still not great.  More points off for having to install Uplay and login to it every time I want to play. I recognize that it's a week after the release of a major title and that the login servers are going to be a bit overburdened, but really? I don't see the point of having to use Uplay in the first place.

For me Watch Dogs was a disappointment. I was looking forward to playing a hacker protagonist, and I hoped this might cultivate a unique main character for once. Unfortunately Ubisoft Montreal completely screwed it up.  The Good:  -Combat system works well, shooting is satisfying.   -Stealth works well and is fun.  -Hacking is easy to do on the fly.  -Environments are highly detailed, and interesting to explore.   -There are a lot of side missions and other activities outside the main story.  The Bad:  -Main character is boring, and horribly realized. He's genuinely a horrible person with almost no likeable features.   -Supporting cast is all right, but again poorly realized.  -The radio stations/media app were all chosen by what I assume to be a 12 year old emo boy. Music sucks, and there is not enough variety.   -Over all sound design is ok, but nothing special.  -POORLY OPTIMIZED PC GRAPHICS!   -Boring mission design.   -Boring story and writing.   -Complete lack of technical terminology and a lack of interesting hacking applications.   -Side activities often appear as *Not Available* for no apparent reason, and without explanation.   -Driving mechanics are horrible, and incredibly annoying.    So to sum it up I would say if your interested in Watch Dogs wait for it to go down in price. This games is not worth the full price investment. The buy line for me would probably be $19.99 or less.

This game is worth about $15. There are some fun things.  However, the good parts of this game become lost in the banality of the overall game expereince.  The story could be from any game. I want to be fighting a maniacal corporation; battling rival hackers. Instead it's an average story that doesn't connect with his life as a hacker, and the writting for what's there is pretty weak, too: For example, one part has you track someone down to a poker game, and you have to slueth out who they are. The game has a fully built poker mini-game, so this could be a really fun moment! Instead, the game never happens, and the guy just runs out for another chase sequene. . Good things in this game are not utilized to their full extent.  The hacking, overall, feels lost: he's stated to be a master hacker, but about the most you'll do with it is to flip traffic lights around and cackle evily. Why doesn't everyone do this? As well, you always have to look at what you're hacking, which just doesn't make sense for hacking computer networks.  I'm frustrated by how slowly computer drivers drive. It's indicitive of how much polish this game still needs: I literally cannot drive slow enough to match pace with other drivers. I like roleplaying, and want to assassinate someone, and then disappear into the crowd, but I can't have that immersion here. Everyone drives so slowly, that I can only go that slow if I let my car idle down and stop. Every other driver is literally driving at the verge of being stopped! It's really frustrating to me. :|  Frankly, the best part of this game is right at the start. You have to evade the police who are searching the streets, but they don't know where exactly you are. That part was great: watching where cop cars are going, and slipping around behind them. . Any other time, the enemy has homing on your location, and goes directly to you. You have to just out drive them--essentially--and once you have, they're all out of your range, so it's not like they're milling about on the street for you to evade; maybe one car, but that's it. I see glimmers of designs I like in this game, but I have to think 'maybe a future game will do this better.'  That's what I think about this game. Maybe the second one will be better; it certainly could be. Ideas like the virtual trips are fun here, but the lame story, annoying controls--which I didn't discuss in depth here, but they are quite bad--and the unpolished face of this game really hamper the good moments in here.

Imho all the bad reviews are either first world problems for example 'omfg, voice sounds like recorded on lowest bitrate', what I can't confirm btw, or are some old reviews from the release phase and atleast since ACU and Far Cry 4 we know, how 'well' Ubisoft manages releases so the game wasn't to blame.  But for the game itself: I enjoy playing it thus far, I like the story, I like the hacking opportunities you have and the love for the detail. Civilians aren't strolling around with one animation, aren't always doing the same and have their stories, sometimes you see them sneeze for example, there you can find a beggar under a bridge, over there a worker at a building site phoning with his wife, telling her what he'd like to do with her next night etc. You can rescue civilians from criminals, thus increasing your reputation with them, which leads them to not calling the police when they see you or atleast doing it only rarely. This works the other way round though, if you walk through the city massacring civilians, they're going to hate you with all the proper consequences ;) The peak of this is, that certain civilians, I don't wanna spoil here too much, react, when you hack their phone and call Blume, the company that is responsible for ctOS, thus increasing your bounty, if you don't stop them from calling Blume.  That leads me to the next part, the multiplayer. It is set in the living world, the streets aren't empty or something like that, it is integrated into the world. As said, some civilians set a bounty on your head for hacking your phone, which makes you a more attractive target for other players, who want to hack your phone or want to tail you, so you got to put a stop to them by finding them and killing them. But this isn't all, there's also the classical Team Deathmatch mode or a Race mode for NFS-Fans and a Free Roam Mode, I haven't tried out yet, I assume, it's some sort of Co-Op-Play but can't guarantee, that this assumption is correct. Also there is the 'ctOS Mobile Challenge', that is linked to a smartphone app. The smartphone player controls the police and another player in the game itself has to escape the police units and drive through checkpoints. So all in all, there is a bit of everything for everyone and It's well made.  Now for technical things: You can use an Xbox-Controller, if you like, don't have one and won't use one. Graphics are amazing even on low settings, I would compare it to GTA 4 even on Low, got no stuttering or anything else on Low, my computer can't take more but if it alrdy looks very good on low, Imagine what it looks like on Ultra, if your PC can handle it. Sound is nice, I don't think, that it has a low quality. The Music you can listen too, well, don't expect too many prominent stars there, Alice Cooper has one track in it but besides that I didn't recognize anyone so don't expect a musical repertoire like in the GTA-Games, Watchdogs is on the loosing side here. The Handling of the Vehicles, well, on Keyboard it is a little edgy, not that smooth as it could be, in comparison to GTA the GTA games do it clearly better. I heard, that you can handle cars more smooth on a controller but since I don't own one, I can't confirm or deny that. A huge downside I experienced is a random crash happening, when Firefox is opened in the background, I don't know if this has to do with my system or the game but I assume the later, since I didn't experience anything similar in other games.  Now for the Price: I bought the game during the sale for -50% off, the digital deluxe edition + Season pass, totalling all in all at around 44€. The standard edition all alone, without any dlc's or digital deluxe content would've cost 29,99€. I thought this game was alright but underwhelming and i cant help feeling this game could have been so much better. Hacking makes up a big part of the game with the ability to hack cameras to observe enemies or to hack traffic lights to cause pursuing enemies to crash. Everything else in the game though just feels tacked on. The combat and stealth gets boring quickly. Missions are repetetive and mostly similar. I dont like the way the DLC was handled either. The only way to get it all is to buy the deluxe edition and season pass but for the most part it's not worth buying anyway.  Good points: -Hacking is fun and the most original feature of the game. I had more fun hacking cameras in areas where enemies were patrolling and causing things to explode to kill them than i did killing enemies the traditional way. - The game looks nice and the city is quite good as well.  Bad points: - The protaganist Aiden just isnt likeable at all and the story isnt very good either. - Stuff like combat and driving could have done with more polish. - Story missions get repetitive as they mostly seem to follow a formula of sneak into an area, hack something then try to escape from pursuing police or fixers. I feel like they could have done so much more with the hacking to add more variety to missions. - As it's an open world Ubisoft game there are of course loads of filler side missions. - The game was quite buggy at times with one particular bug causing me to repeatedly fail a story mission. Luckily i found a workaround on the internet but it's pretty unforgiveable to have something like that left unfixed. - The way DLC was handled in a pretty greedy fashion. Want all the DLC? Well you have to buy the season pass and Deluxe Edition. However excluding Bad Blood the DLC is mostly crap and just adds cosmetic stuff of a couple side missions which aren't great anyway.  Overall i cant really recommend this game unless you can pick it up really cheap. Dont bother with any DLC apart from Bad Blood which adds a new campaign and isnt too bad a campaign at that.

REVIEW ON WATCH DOGS   (spoilers In a way)    Ive been playing this enough to know the main importance of the game. Lets start with the good things, The concept of the hacking is amazing. There are so many things to do with hacking going from destroying a whole gang with just the things around them or doing a complete chase where you have the advantage from putting bridges up to putting up road spikes to block their path. Also I love the details, I love how much effort they put into making it feel like your just another criminal or vigilante in chicago. With all the different types of areas there are to all the different hot spots and stores there are. The final great thing about this is the all of the side quests you can do. There are side quests everywhere going from random criminal activity to destroying a whole gang going all the way to transporting cars while getting chased by the police. It adds so much more experience without having to do the campaign. Also its a good way not to get bored.  Now lets get onto the bad things about Watch_Dogs, We all know when a game first comes out it will have some bugs here and there. Until the next couple updates expect some of this, You will experience lag when drive to fast, sometimes when you go to a new location it will lag, and sometimes it will take forever to find people online. Another bad thing are the AI's They are terrible at reacting to things. When you see AI's you would usually open a profiler and see what they are like or who they are or what type of aids or etc, but no one realizes how they react to things. When you run into them and their car is severly damaged or just is not on the road wouldnt u think they should get out of that car and see whats going on or would you just let them act normally and drive like it was any other day. Also when a car is on fire they just run away and no one else does its just them. Its common sense to run away from a burning car isnt it? Finally I think they need to fix how easy it is to get money. If you just keep your profiler on and just go straight in the downtown part of chicago it is so easy to find people with bank accounts/rich bank accounts. All you do is hack them and make sure its not a blume affiliate. You can literally make 50k in 5-10 minutes by walking. You can do this right after the first mission too so my recommendation is try and make it feel harder to get money by either not using profiler as much or just dont hack bank accounts.   My rating: 7/10 By the game? !YES! p.s try and focus on the good things A.I's dont matter most of the time anyways
